original_definition: 'energy performance of a building' means the calculated or measured amount of energy needed to meet the energy demand associated with a typical use of the building, which includes, inter alia, energy used for heating, cooling, ventilation, hot water and lighting;
generated_definition: 'energy performance of a building' means the energy performance of a building refers to the measure of the energy efficiency of a building in terms of its ability to maintain a comfortable internal environment while using minimal energy. it includes the energy consumption of the building for heating, cooling, ventilation, and hot water production, as well as the energy losses due to inefficiencies in the building's envelope, such as air leaks and thermal bridging.

Article 31: The energy performance of a building shall be determined on the basis of the calculated or actual annual energy that is consumed in order to meet the different needs associated with its typical use and shall reflect the heating energy needs and cooling energy needs (energy needed to avoid overheating) to maintain the envisaged temperature conditions of the building, and domestic hot water needs.
